title: Why does lore explain and then misdiscribe Petricite
body:
Petricite (known as the trees) are cut down and then made into a formula that involves the Petricite (wood)  and mixed with Ash and Lime (I presume the rock), to then make Petricite (Steel?).

Petricite (Steel / Less Wood?) is from that point claimed to be part of a steel component in Petricite Steel or simpley a Rock/Stone.

Why is that, i wonder?

Edit: I'm not trying to be aggressive by the way, even though I've been in a super bad mood lately ;p
I just felt there was inconsistency, but I had a slight misunderstanding about Petrified Forest and 'Petricite Grove'. 
I assumed the trees were like that 'naturally (in a magical world sense..?)'. 
Now I'm curious I'd they were magical PRIOR to the petrification or the petrification is (extra?) magical in nature

replies.body:
Petricite is not the name of the living trees/wood. It very specifically refers only to those **petri**fied trees in Demacia - I'm not sure anyone currently alive in Runeterra knows what the original trees were, or what they were called.

They also aren't (currently?) growing, and so petricite is a finite resource. Once it's all been harvested/mined/whatever, that's it. Tick tock, Jarvan...

(Real-world talk, the name was likely just derived from _petrification_, which literally means something organic turned into stone, or becoming stone-like. The suffix -cite comes - I *think* - from Greek, and there are lots of organic stone-like compounds with names like anthracite, etc. It's a fantastical name created by a Rioter before my time, meaning "magical trees which have turned to stone".)

Well yeah its Greek derived.
Petra is rock. (Sadly I'm greek and can understand a decent amount of greek but cant read/write or speak it well)
Ified is to make something into likeness

Liquified make something like liquid, petrified ti make something like rock

I think I misunderstood petricite grove/petrified Forest then.

Would/were the trees magic absorbant prior to being petrified and grew/looked as regular trees?

(I assumed they grew as they were and just had a different consistency than regular trees).

Petricite a finite resource? This could open various lore possibilities:

If there's no more petricite, then what would become of the World Runes that Ryze is storing? Without a source of suppression, could all World Runes in one place become so volatile that it could signal a worldwide apocalypse, or perhaps something greater yet equally dangerous?

What will the Demacians do afterwards? Will they have to make do with what they have (and perhaps embrace the practice of magic to combat magic) or flee and find a new place, which is highly unlikely?

How will Noxus and other regions respond to this?

What will be the natural implications and consequences once all Petricite is used up?

This is what we know:

- The trees' Petricite (if it is indeed called that) is unrefined or just not usable for the construction work Demacians want, it is mixed with ash and lime to make the more conventional Petricite we see in cities.

- Demacian/Rune/Silver/what I assume you're calling Petricite Steel is not actually confirmed to have Petricite in it but a lot of people believe it does due to Demacian Steel having in-built resistance against magic. [For some more info which does point to a link between them:](https://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/en-us/2019/02/ask-riot-game-modes-metals/)

> What kind of metal alloys exist in Runeterra? Is Garen’s sword made with petricite? What about Darius’s axe?
> 
> There are many, many different metals and metalworking traditions across Runeterra. Certainly we know of gold, silver, iron, lead, copper, and many more besides—perhaps even some that do not exist in the real world, as well.
> 
> Adding powdered rock to the finest steel would likely result in… well, weaker steel. However, the weaponsmiths of the Great City are certainly using petricite for something, and it has been claimed that Demacian steel can offer some resistance to magic. Maybe one day, we’ll find out the truth?

Worth noting that Garen's sword is Sunsteel, which may be a different alloy or metal but appears to be one of the weapons Kayle blessed in her youth. [As well as:](https://map.leagueoflegends.com/en_US)

That would be coherent and interesting

I *believe* that Petricite (steel) is likely metal forged using Petricite (wood) as a fuel source that imparts magical qualities to the finished material, while Petricite (rock) is mixed with Ash and Lime as a building material. Further, I also believe only the latter is *called* Petricite officially.

Petricite is a stone that's made from the petrified trees, ash, and lime. It's not called Petricite unless it is in the refined stone state.

The stone compound, Petricite, is then used with steel and metal to form the alloys that Demacia uses in its armor and weaponry.

If the stone compound itself is referred to as a metal, it's likely referring to the alloy, or, it's just Riot's own people not being on the same page as their existing information. This has happened before at Riot.
They are called Petricite (trees) in the Petricite (Forest) and part of the ingredients in Petricite is Petricite.

Galio's bio, where Petricite really first was introduced to us, does not refer to the petrified trees as petricite. It only calls it petricite once the stone compound has been formed.

As I mentioned above though, Riot is fairly notorious for not being consistent across their various writers, so it could just be ignorant misuse of the terminology.
My gosh, why don't they just make official names already.
